Available online 15 November 2021 Review In situ studies of energy-related electrochemical reactions using Raman and X-ray absorption spectroscopy Heng-Quan Chen Lie Zou Di-Ye Wei Ling-Ling Zheng * Yuan-Fei Wu Hua Zhang Jian-Feng Li # College of Energy, State Key Laboratory of Physical Chemistry of Solid Surfaces, iChEM, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, College of Materials, Fujian Key Laboratory of Advanced Materials, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361005, Fujian, China College of Energy State Key Laboratory of Physical Chemistry of Solid Surfaces iChEM College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering College of Materials Fujian Key Laboratory of Advanced Materials Xiamen University Xiamen Fujian 361005 China College of Energy, State Key Laboratory of Physical Chemistry of Solid Surfaces, iChEM, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, College of Materials, Fujian Key Laboratory of Advanced Materials, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361005, Fujian, China * Corresponding author # Corresponding author ABSTRACT Electrochemical energy conversion technologies involving processes such as water splitting and O2/CO2 reduction, provide promising solutions for addressing global energy scarcity and minimizing adverse environmental impact. However, due to a lack of an in-depth understanding of the reaction mechanisms and the nature of the active sites, further advancement of these techniques has been limited by the development of efficient and robust catalysts. Therefore, in situ characterization of these electrocatalytic processes under working conditions is essential. In this review, recent applications of in situ Raman spectroscopy and X-ray absorption spectroscopy for various nano- and single-atom catalysts in energy-related reactions are summarized. Notable cases are highlighted, including the capture of oxygen-containing intermediate species formed during the reduction of oxygen and oxidation of hydrogen, and the detection of catalyst structural transformations occurring with the change in potential during the evolution of oxygen and reduction of CO2. Finally, the challenges and outlook for advancing in situ spectroscopic technologies to gain a deeper fundamental understanding of these energy-related electrocatalytic processes are discussed. Keywords Raman spectroscopy X-ray absorption spectroscopy In situ characterization Electrocatalysis Energy conversion and storage 1 Introduction Challenges regarding energy production, storage, and conversion have become a central topic worldwide, occupying the headlines of major news media, which indirectly illustrates the importance of finding sustainable approaches to address these issues for the survival and development of humanity. Thus, a gradual divorce from traditional energy conversion technologies is necessary to avoid the disastrous consequences of unsustainable energy consumption and production, such as global warming, desertification, and ozone holes. Owing to years of unremitting research and exploration, numerous advanced technologies for clean energy conversion have been developed, including fuel cells, metal-air batteries, and water-splitting cells [1–4]. The electrochemical reduction and evolution of oxygen are two critical reactions that determine the performance and efficiency of these clean-energy devices, as they are dependent on the sluggish reaction kinetics and large overpotentials associated with these processes [4–6]. In addition to the oxygen reduction/evolution reaction (ORR/OER), the importance of the hydrogen evolution/oxidation reaction (HER/HOR) cannot be ignored, as hydrogen can function as a powerful fuel, emitting only water [6]. The conversion of CO2 to value-added carbon-based materials, such as ethylene, ethanol, and acetic acid, not only enriches the source of clean fuels but also artificially closes the carbon cycle, hence, the CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) is another important electrochemical reaction [7–10]. All of the above-mentioned electrocatalytic reactions occur at the solid-liquid or solid-gas interface, and catalysts are generally utilized to promote such reactions by reducing the overpotential or altering the reaction pathway. Thus, to accelerate interfacial electrochemical reactions, the development of efficient and robust electrochemical catalysts is critical, which in turn relies on an in-depth understanding of reaction mechanisms and intermediate processes, especially at the molecular or atomic level [11]. However, attaining such fundamental understanding remains significantly challenging because of a lack of real-time and direct in situ experimental information [12]. Although various ex situ technologies can offer insights into the compositional, morphological, and electronic characteristics of catalysts, the reliability of these data is difficult to guarantee because the structural transformation and reconstruction of active sites would occur under working conditions. Theoretical simulations, such as density functional theory (DFT) calculations, have emerged as powerful tools for studying possible reaction pathways. However, the accuracy of such simulations is strongly dependent on the model structures used, which are built based on experimental information, especially those acquired under in situ or working conditions. Such discrepancies have spurred the development of in situ characterization technologies that can track the dynamic catalytic processes, capture short-lived intermediates, and reveal reactive sites, including in situ Raman spectroscopy, infrared spectroscopy (IR), and X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) [6,11,13]. In this study, selected applications of in situ spectroscopic techniques, including Raman spectroscopy and XAS, for investigating various electrochemical reactions (ORR, OER, HOR, HER, and CO2RR) are summarized. Notable cases are highlighted, wherein the molecular structure of the reaction intermediates and the nature of the active sites were investigated using these in situ techniques. In addition, the disadvantages of these technologies are discussed in detail. Finally, the challenges and future developments of these spectroscopic technologies are discussed. 2 Brief introduction to Raman spectroscopy and XAS As powerful techniques for molecular fingerprint identification, IR and Raman spectroscopy have been widely utilized for in situ surface analysis. However, IR spectroscopy is susceptible to interference from water and it is difficult to access the low wavenumber region, which contains information on oxygen-bearing intermediate species [11]. In contrast to IR, Raman spectroscopy, especially surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS), has been demonstrated as a powerful technique that can provide in-depth information on oxygen species, hydroxy groups, and metal-molecule bonds. Meanwhile, synchrotron-based XAS has been established as a powerful tool for probing the electronic structure and chemical bonding of catalysts. In addition, it is regarded as the most effective technique for detecting the coordination environment and valence state of the target element [11]. Therefore, we believe that in situ Raman spectroscopy represents the optimal choice for investigating oxygen-containing intermediates during the above-mentioned electrochemical reactions, while in situ XAS is ideally suited for monitoring the changes in the coordination environment and valence state of the active sites. Thus, this review focuses primarily on recent advancements of these two techniques. 2.1 Raman spectroscopy Raman spectroscopy is a powerful technique used for molecular fingerprint recognition based on the inelastic scattering of light by target molecules [14]. However, owing to its limited sensitivity, it has only been used for the characterization of bulk catalysts until the discovery of SERS in 1977 [14–17]. The development of SERS can be divided into four stages [18]. In the 1970s, SERS was first employed to probe the intermediate during a catalytic process on the surface of Ag (Fig. 1 ) [19]. However, a strong SERS effect was only observed for several specific materials that exhibit low catalytic activity, such as Cu, Ag, and Au, limiting its further application. To expand this technique for detecting other catalytically active materials, a borrowing strategy was developed, which entails depositing the target catalyst on the surface of the SERS active substrate (Fig. 1) [20,21]. Another significant breakthrough was the invention of shell-isolated nanoparticle-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SHINERS) by our group in 2010 [22]. In this technique, Au nanoparticles act as cores that are surrounded by thin, pinhole-free silica shells. The Au cores serve as signal amplifiers, while the pinhole-free silica shells effectively isolate the target molecule from adsorbing to the core thus eliminating the associated influence. The SHINERS-satellite strategy, designed for the in situ characterization of nanocatalysts, is the most recent SERS development (Fig. 1) [23–25]. Practical nanocatalysts are assembled on the surface of shell-isolated nanoparticles (SHINs), which can generate strong electromagnetic fields to enhance the Raman signal of the catalytic nanoparticles. 2.2 XAS spectroscopy Based on the use of synchrotron radiation sources, XAS has become a powerful technique for detecting local atomic and electronic structures that govern the activity and selectivity of complex catalysts [13]. Generally, XAS includes both X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS). The region between 50 eV below the absorption edge and 20 eV above the absorption edge is pertinent to XANES, utilized for identifying the electronic structure and valence state of the target element. The region ranging up to ~1000 eV above the absorption is relevant to EXAFS, which is used to reveal the coordination environment of the studied element. However, XAS measurements are bulk-sensitive, and thus only reveal the average valence state and coordination numbers of the whole bulk catalyst [11], while it is widely acknowledged that these electrocatalytic reactions occur mainly at the surface active sites. This drawback has prompted the development of the delta-mu(Δμ)-XANES method, which is a surface-sensitive technique [26]. Combined with the results of theoretical calculations, Mukerjee et al. [27,28] used Δμ-XANES to reveal the oxygen coverage of catalysts at varying potentials. 3 Oxygen reduction reaction Being the cathodic reaction of fuel cells and air-metal batteries, the ORR is a complicated reaction involving either two-step two-electron transfer or four-electron transfer [29]. The four-electron pathway is generally preferred for the purpose of improving the efficiency [4]. However, for the four-electron pathway, two possible reactive mechanisms can occur, namely, the associative or dissociative mechanism [30]. Taking the acidic ORR as an example, these two mechanisms are proposed to proceed as follows: Associative mechanism: (1) O2 + * → O2* (2) O2* + H+ + e− → OOH* (3) OOH*+ H+ + e− → O* + H2O (4) O* + H+ + e− → OH* (5) OH* + H+ + e− → H2O where * refers to an active site on a certain surface. Alternatively, the dissociative mechanism proceeds as follows. (6) O2 + 2* → 2O* (7) 2O* + 2H+ + 2e− → 2OH* (8) 2OH* + 2H+ + 2e− → 2H2O The only difference between these two possible mechanisms is the formation of OOH* species. Using DFT calculations, Liang et al. [30] proposed that the initial oxygen dissociative energy barrier on a catalytic interface determines the mechanism. If the dissociative energy barrier of a given surface is high, the dissociative mechanism may not be favorable, as exemplified by the majority of carbon surfaces. However, this has not been confirmed experimentally as real-time observation of the catalytic process and the capture of short-lived intermediates has not been achieved. In addition, with the aim of replacing expensive Pt catalysts, an increasing number of non-platinum catalysts have been explored [31–34]. However, the development of non-platinum catalysts relies on an in-depth understanding of their active sites and pathways. To this end, in situ spectroscopic technologies are considered powerful methods for monitoring the catalytic process and elucidating active sites and mechanisms. 3.1 Pt single crystal electrodes Compared with polycrystalline Pt, single-crystal Pt is more representative, homogenous, and easier to model [35]. Thus, it is of vital importance to study the nature of the ORR on the surface of single-crystal Pt surfaces as a way of bridging experimental observations and theoretical simulations. Our group has invented SHINERS and employed it to investigate the ORR process on various low-index single-crystal Pt surfaces [36]. Rotating disk electrode (RDE) test results showed that the ORR activities of each Pt low-index single-crystal differed, following the order of: (111) > (100) > (110) [36]. Figs. 2(a) )–2(c) display the in situ SHINERS spectra of ORR on low-index single-crystal Pt surfaces. Verified by the deuterium isotopic experiment, the Raman peak located at ~732 cm–1 on Pt (111) was attributed to the O-O stretching vibration of the OOH* species (Fig. 2(a))), indicative of the associative mechanism. This Raman peak was absent at a similar position on Pt (100) and Pt (110), while a Raman band at ~1080 cm–1 appeared on their surfaces, resulting from the bending mode of Pt-OH (Fig. 2(b)) and 2(c)). These findings demonstrate that distinct ORR mechanisms occur depending on the nature of the low-index single-crystal Pt surface. Owing to the lower coordination number and more accessible surface structure, high-index single-crystal Pt surfaces exhibit higher ORR activities than the corresponding low-index surfaces [37]. To deepen the understanding of the underlying mechanism and provide a guide for the design of highly active ORR catalysts, our group has also investigated catalytic processes on high-index single-crystal Pt surfaces using in situ SHINERS. Both OH* and OOH* intermediate species were observed on Pt (311) and Pt (211) planes during the ORR process (Figs. 2(d)) and 2(e)), indicating that a similar associative mechanism was operational [36]. However, the intensities of the characteristic OOH* peaks were different for Pt (211) and Pt (311), accounting for their distinct activities (Fig. 2(f))). Based on these findings, as well as those of DFT calculations, we proposed that the stronger adsorption onto the Pt (311) plane would hinder the dissociation of OOH* species and thus lower its ORR activity. 3.2 Pt-based alloy catalysts In consideration of practical applications, alloying Pt with transition metals (TMs) to form Pt-based alloys has been recognized as one of the most effective strategies for improving the catalytic performance of Pt for the ORR [38]. The increase in activity is usually attributed to the ligand and/or strain effect, which indicates that the introduction of a second or third component lowers the binding energy between Pt and oxygen [39]. However, the real role of TMs and their specific ORR mechanism have not been elucidated due to a lack of direct spectral evidence. To this end, our group has developed a borrowing strategy to study the ORR process on the surface of PtNi alloys [40]. As shown in Fig. 3(a) ), a uniform PtNi shell was deposited on Au nanoparticles. This method enables the amplification of Raman signals of the intermediates generated during the ORR process by the electromagnetic field excited by plasmons from the Au core. The OOH* signal was also observed during the catalytic process of PtNi, indicative of the associative mechanism (Fig. 3(b))). In addition, we discovered that the frequency of OOH* absorption was closely related to the Ni content. An increase in Ni content resulted in a prominent red shift of the Raman band of OOH* (Fig. 3(c))) [40]. Thus, it was revealed that the addition of Ni could influence the OOH* binding energy on the Pt surface, and we could optimize the ORR activity of the catalysts by adjusting the Ni doping content. Although the borrowing strategy is suitable for revealing the in situ oxygen reduction process of Pt-based alloys, traditional Pt-based catalysts are usually small nanoparticles that are relatively distinct from the morphology present in the borrowing strategy. Thus, there is an urgent need for the development of new methods that overcome this limitation and extend SERS analysis to practical nanocatalysts. Recently, our group has developed a SHINERS-satellite strategy for studying the in situ ORR on Pt-based alloys [41]. Employing this strategy, Pt3Co nanoparticles synthesized via a thermal decomposition method were assembled on the surface of SHINs using a charge-induced self-assembly method (Fig. 4(a) )). Adsorbed O2* and OOH* were both investigated in acidic and basic electrolytes, while OH* could also be detected at the Co site in alkaline solution (Fig. 4(b)) and 4(c)). Thus, the associative mechanism of Pt3Co in both acidic and alkaline environments was revealed. 3.3 metal-nitrogen-carbon (M-N-C) catalysts The first application of M-N-C for ORR catalysis dates back to the 1960s, when Jasinski [42] first discovered the ORR activity of phthalocyanine cobalt. In 2011, Dodelet’s group [43] reported zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF)-derived Fe-N-C catalysts that function as cathodic catalysts for fuel cells, and the test results showed that this fuel cell exhibited a power density of 0.75 W∙cm–1 at 0.6 V, comparable to that of a platinum group metal (PGM)-based fuel cell. Inspired by these gratifying results, numerous M-N-C catalysts have been explored to replace expensive Pt for catalyzing the ORR. Although considerable effort has been devoted to elucidating the nature of M-N-C catalyst active sites, a number of controversies remain [44,45]. To summarize, there are three main viewpoints on what constitutes M-N-C active sites: (1) metal-nitrogen moieties embedded in carbon defect sites [44,46]; (2) nitrogen-carbon moieties [47]; (3) metal species encapsulated by nitrogen-doped carbon [48]. The difficulties in solving these arguments lie in: (1) the coexistence of these three sites in the pyrolyzed M-N-C catalysts, and (2) the lack of effective in situ characterization techniques. Recently, in a study by Li et al. [45], in situ XAS experiments were performed to reveal the nature of the active sites and reaction mechanism in a MOF-derived FePhenMOF-ArNH3 catalyst. As displayed in Fig. 5(a) ), the Fe k-edge shifted toward a higher energy with an increase in the applied potential, revealing the Fe2+/3+ redox transition. In addition, an increase in the intensity of the Fe-O/N peak was observed (Fig. 5(b))), indicating the adsorption of OH*. Furthermore, their corresponding Δμ-XANES spectra (Fig. 5(c))) were agreement with the theoretical Δμ-XANES of the FeN4C8 model containing an axially bonded oxygen atom (Fig. 5(d))). Thus, the following transformation in the O2-saturated electrolyte was deduced: (9) Fe2+-N4 + 1/2O2 + H+ + e– → OH*-Fe3+-N4 Consequently, combining their ex situ characterization results, they proposed that the non-planar Fe2+-N4 moiety embedded on a carbon support may be the active site for the ORR. In their subsequent work with Xing’s group [49], they further confirmed that OH*-Fe2+-N4 is likely to be the active site. Jia et al. [50] systematically studied the influence of Fe-N switching behavior on the ORR activity through in situ XAS experiments. By controlling the pyrolysis temperature, they obtained three types of Fe-N4 structures, termed D1, D2, and D3 (Fig. 5(e))). The in situ XAS results revealed that the dynamic Fe-N4 structure associated with the Fe2+/3+ redox transition likely determines the catalyst activity, rather than the static structure with bare sites. Tong et al. [51] used in situ XAS technology to reveal the synergistic mechanism of a Cu/Zn dual-metal single-atom catalyst for the ORR. During their experiments, they discovered that the Cu-N4 site functioned as the main active ORR site with the cooperation of Zn-N4, and that it would undergo changes from atomic dispersion to cluster and then return to atomic dispersion. 4 Oxygen evolution reaction Although this reaction process is opposite to that of the ORR, the common features shared by OER and ORR are the sluggish kinetics and high overpotentials [52,53]. Thus, there is an urgent need for developing advanced catalysts for the OER to improve the overall efficiency of water splitting. In this context, an in-depth understanding of active sites and OER mechanisms is essential for guiding rational catalyst design. 4.1 Metal oxides/hydroxides As is well known, most catalysts are unstable under the potential at which the OER occurs, which raises the question of whether the active species is the original catalyst or another newly formed species [54]. Another long-standing uncertainty is the reaction mechanism of the OER. The proposed mechanism of the OER in alkaline electrolyte is as follows [55–57]: (10) M + OH− → MOH + e− (11) MOH + OH− → MO + H2O + e− (12) 2MO → 2M + O2 (13) MO + OH− → MOOH + e− (14) MOOH → M + O2(g) + H+ + e− where M represents metal. There are two possible pathways for forming oxygen from MO. One route follows Eq. (12), and the other, Eqs. (13) to (14). The main difference between the two pathways is the formation of MOOH. Current state-of-the-art OER catalysts are precious metal oxides, including RuO2 and IrO2, owing to their low overpotential at high current densities. However, their scarcity and prohibitive costs hinder their large-scale application. Recently, transition metal oxides/hydroxides have emerged as promising candidates for OER catalysis owing to their abundant active sites and tunable electronic structures [6]. In a representative study performed by Yeo et al. [58], Co3O4 was deposited on the surface of an Au core to catalyze the OER. Their in situ SERS measurements revealed that the initially deposited Co3O4 was progressively oxidized to CoO(OH) with increasing potential. In addition, the uniformly dispersed Co sites on the Au core promoted the formation of Co4+ species, which are believed to be essential for enhancing activity (Figs. 6(a) )–6(d)). In another study, Huang et al. [59] observed the surface restructure of prepared Ni-based materials (NiNPS) during a harsh OER process using in situ Raman spectroscopy. With increasing potential, NiNPS underwent an irreversible transformation, morphing to α-Ni(OH)2, which then underwent a reversible transformation to λ-Ni(OH)2 (Figs. 6(e))–6(f)). These interesting findings revealed that the presence of λ-Ni(OH)2 is crucial for high OER activity. Moreover, a similar phase transformation of Ni was observed by Edvinsson’s group [60] in their synthesized NiFe layered double hydroxide (LDH) OER catalyst. Additionally, with the aid of an 18O-labeling experiment, Koper’s group provided spectroscopic evidence for the existence of a superoxo-type species (NiOO−) during the OER process when NiOOH was used as a catalyst [61]. In their later work, they employed in situ SERS to study the effect of alkali cations on the activity of NiOOH in the OER [62]. The results of their research indicated that the cation may interact with NiOO− and form NiOO−-M+. The excellent stability of NiOO−-Cs+ may be attributed to its high activity. 4.2 Non-oxide catalysts To improve the efficiency and lower catalyst cost, numerous non-oxide catalysts have been explored to replace the traditional metal oxides/hydroxides. Among them, transition metal chalcogenides have emerged as one of the most promising OER catalysts [63]. Accordingly, it is necessary to gain a comprehensive understanding of in situ reaction processes. With the aid of in situ Raman spectroscopy, Zhang’s group studied the entire catalytic process of NiSe2 [64]. The initial catalysts exhibited two characteristic Raman bands located at 216 and 244 cm–1, resulting from the Ag and Tg models of Se-Se stretching, respectively (Fig. 7(a) )). With increasing potential, new peaks appeared at 477 and 554 cm–1 at a potential of 1.38 V, indicating the formation of NiOOH. The intensities of the two peaks increased with increasing voltage, supporting the notion that the Ni in the initial NiS2 had been oxidized. The peak that appeared at 807 cm–1 under a potential of 1.23 V and disappeared at 1.53 V was assigned to SeO3 2–, while the Raman band at 834 cm–1, increasing in intensity, was attributed to SeO4 2–. Thus, they inferred that the Se in the initial samples was progressively oxidized to SeO3 2– as the potential increased, to finally become SeO4 2–. In addition, in situ XAS measurements have been implemented to provide deeper insights into the transformation process of this type of catalyst. Shen’s group synthesized CoS x nanovesicles coated with an FeS x heterophase for the OER [65]. Their analyses of in situ XAS revealed that the incorporation of FeS x promoted the transformation of CoS x to active CoOOH because of the increased valence state of Co and reduced coordination number of the Co sites. As with transition metal chalcogenides, transition metal pnictides and carbides have also been recognized as promising OER catalysts. In a typical study by Chen’s group [66], in situ XAS was performed to probe the transient state of Fe-doped CoP during catalysis (Figs. 7(b)) and 7(c)). Their analysis results showed that CoP would be promptly converted to Co(OH)2 with increasing potential. The Fe dopant stabilized the phosphide phase and promoted the conversion to Co oxyhydroxide, which is highly active for the OER. Bimetallic carbide Mo6Ni6C was prepared by Zu et al. [67] to enhance the OER activity. In situ XAS characterization revealed that the catalysts were first converted to MoNi clusters. Then, the Mo in the alloy was oxidized to Mo6+ and incorporated into NiOOH providing the real active site for the OER. Recently, the rapid development of single-atom catalysts (SACs) has provided new concepts and methods for the design of high-efficiency OER catalysts [68]. Bai et al. [69] reported that a single-atom Co catalyst could be converted to a Co-Fe dual-site single-atom catalyst for OER catalysis. Their in situ XAS measurements showed that Fe was inserted into the catalyst to form an Fe-Co moiety during activation of the initial SAC, likely through one or two bridging OHs (Fig. 7(d))). The newly formed Fe-Co site functions as an active site for the OER. 5 Hydrogen evolution/oxidation reaction 5.1. Hydrogen oxidation reaction A comprehensive understanding of the HOR mechanism in alkaline systems is the basis for the rational design of HOR catalysts. Even with the unremitting efforts of a large number of researchers, this remains a widely debated topic [70,71]. In acidic electrolytes, the HOR may follow the Heyrovsky-Volmer or Tafel-Volmer mechanism [71]. Hydrogen is absorbed onto the catalyst surface to form H*, which is in turn converted to a proton by releasing an electron. Thus, it is widely acknowledged that the hydrogen binding energy (HBE) can serve as an active descriptor for HOR activity [72–74]. However, the role of OH– in the base solution remains unclear. The two possible pathways for the alkaline HOR are as follows: Pathway 1 (15) H* → H+ + e− + * (16) OH− + H+ → H2O Pathway 2 (17) OH− + *′ → OH*′ + e− (18) H* + OH*′ → H2O + *′ + * As displayed in pathway 1, H* releases an electron and reacts with OH− to form water, similar to the case in acidic electrolytes. However, in the second route, OH− is adsorbed on the catalyst surface and then combined with the adsorbed H* to form a water molecule. Thus, the real role of OH− would determine whether HBE acts as the only active descriptor for HOR catalysts. However, owing to a lack of effective observation methods, this conundrum has not been resolved. In a representative study by our group, a uniform PtNi alloy shell was deposited on Au nanoparticle (NP) cores [75]. Using the borrowing strategy, we performed in situ SERS characterization. As shown in Fig. 8(a) ), no Raman bands were observed for the surface of Au@Pt in the potential range for the HOR. In contrast, when the potential reached 65 mV, the surface of Au@PtNi gave rise to a pronounced Raman signal at 778 cm–1 (Fig. 8(b))). Based on the results of deuterium isotopic experiments and DFT calculations, we surmised that this peak may result from the rocking mode of OH* on the Ni-Ni bridge site. This finding provides compelling evidence for the role of OH− in the HOR catalytic process. Moreover, a similar phenomenon was observed in a study conducted by Jia et al. [76]. They employed in situ XAS technology to probe the presence of OH* on the Ru sites in both PtRu/C and Ru/C catalysts during the HOR process. As shown in Figs. 8(c)) and 8(d), the Ru k-edge shifted positively with an increase in the applied potential for both Ru/C and PtRu/C. Their derived Δμ-XANES corresponded well with the theoretical Δμ-XANES of Ru clusters containing an axially coordinated OH* (Figs. 8(e)) and 8(f)), confirming the promoting role of OH* for the Volmer step of PtRu via facilitation of the oxidation of adsorbed H on Pt sites. These important spectroscopic findings provide valuable insights for elucidating long-standing enigmas and lay the foundation for the design of high-efficiency HOR catalysts. 5.2 Hydrogen evolution reaction The development of high-efficiency, low-cost catalysts for scalable hydrogen production is a crucial objective [77]. In addition to traditional Pt-based catalysts, an increasing number of new materials with attractive HER performances have been reported, including transition metal chalcogenides, transition metal phosphides, and SACs [78,79]. The emergence of these catalysts also presents a new unknown: the nature of their active sites. Transition metal chalcogenides have been reported as one of the most promising catalysts for the HER, but their source of activity in the catalytic reaction is still unclear, hindering further application [78]. Yano’s group [80] conducted in situ XAS measurements on the surface of amorphous molybdenum sulfide (MoS x ) and found that the as-prepared MoS x was reduced to MoS2 under the potential at which the HER occurred. Recently, through cooperation with Zhang’s team, our group [81] employed in situ SERS to study the catalytic HER process on Ag@MoS2 core-shell catalysts. A Raman peak was detected under –200 mV (vs. RHE), resulting from the stretching vibration of S‒H (Figs. 9(a) ) and 9(b)), which clearly indicated that the active center of MoS2 in the HER reaction is the S atom. Owing to their remarkable catalytic performance and maximum atom utilization efficiency, SACs have emerged as a new class of attractive catalysts [68]. Moreover, their relatively uniform structure and well-defined sites serve as an ideal model for detecting their active sites and mechanisms. Cao et al. [82] used in situ EXAFS to reveal the dynamic active-site structure of Co SACs during the electrocatalytic HER. They found that the coordination-unsaturated Co site may undergo structural and valence-state conversion into a high-oxidation HO-Co1-N2 moiety. This finding combined with DFT calculation results led them to conclude that the high-oxidation Co sites were responsible for its high activity. Zhao et al. [83] reported a single-atom nickel-iodide (Ni-I) catalyst for the electrocatalytic HER in alkaline environments. In situ Raman spectroscopy revealed that the adsorbed H atom bonded to I to form an H-I intermediate during the electrochemical process (Figs. 9(c)) and 9(d)). 6 CO2 reduction reaction The electrochemical CO2RR has been recognized as a potential method for attaining a sustainable carbon cycle because it can couple carbon capture storage with renewable energy to produce valuable chemical feedstocks and fuels [9,84,85]. However, the complexity of the CO2RR reaction far exceeds that of all of the above-discussed reactions, and the pathway is highly dependent on the properties of the catalyst and the experimental parameters. A selection of typical reaction products with varying electron transfer numbers are listed in Table 1 . The ideal practical CO2RR catalyst should have high product selectivity and Faraday efficiency, as well as a low reaction overpotential [85]. Over the last decade, significant efforts have been devoted to screening potential catalysts for the CO2RR. However, the harsh environment wherein the catalysts generally function raises the question regarding the nature of the active sites under strongly reductive conditions. 6.1 Copper-based catalysts Copper-based catalysts have been extensively studied for accessing valuable hydrocarbons via the CO2RR owing to their low overpotential [86]. However, these catalysts are generally unselective, and some low-value compounds are generally produced along with high-value C2 products [87]. To improve their catalytic selectivity, considerable efforts have been devoted to modifying the composition and electronic structure of these Cu-based catalysts. In a typical study by Ren et al. [88], Zn was doped into Cu-based oxides for CO2RR catalysis. By optimizing the doping amount of Zn, the selectivity of C2H5OH versus C2H4 could be tuned to ~12.5. In situ Raman measurements were conducted to investigate the transformation of the catalysts during the CO2RR. The characteristic Raman peaks of oxidized Cu and Zn gradually attenuated and then disappeared under a constant potential of –0.85 V (vs. RHE) (Figs. 10(a) )–10(d)). The appearance of peaks at 280, 365, and 2060 cm–1 suggested that the Cu-oxide catalysts converted to a metallic state during the CO2RR. Thus, they proposed a two-site mechanism to rationalize the selectivity for ethanol. In another study performed by Vasilef et al. [89], the alloying of copper was proposed to change the adsorption behavior of the intermediate species and thus alter its selectivity. By increasing the Sn content in the prepared Cu-Sn alloy, the selectivity shifted from CO to HCOOH generation. Their in situ spectroscopic results revealed that the low Sn content in the alloy favors the pathway to CO via a C-bound intermediate, *COOH, while the alloy with higher Sn content may prefer the pathway to HCOOH via an O-bound *OCHO intermediate (Figs. 10(e))–10(h)). In situ XAS measurements have also been performed to detect the chemical states of the active Cu species in Cu-based catalysts. Mistry et al. [90] employed tunable plasma treatment to prepare a series of excellent Cu oxide catalysts for electrochemical CO2RR with low overpotentials and high selectivity for C2H4. As displayed in Fig. 10(i)), during the initial 15 min of the reaction, both Cu and Cu2O features were present, while no Cu2O features were discernable after 1 h. Their corresponding EXAFS results suggested that Cu+ species may remain relatively stable on the surface, providing direct evidence that Cu+ species are important for improving C2H2 selectivity. 6.2 Non-copper catalysts Tin-based catalysts have also been extensively studied during the CO2RR process because of their high selectivity for formate or formic acid, which serve as value-added substances for fuel cells [6]. However, the selectivity for formic acid is highly dependent on the chemical state, morphology, and working conditions of Sn. Thus, in situ spectroscopic technologies have been employed to detect the changes in Sn-based catalysts during the catalytic process. Dutta et al. [91] utilized in situ Raman spectroscopy to monitor the oxidation state changes of SnO2. A correlation between the oxidation state of the surface and the Faradaic efficiency (FE) of formate production was observed; at a moderate potential, SnO2 exhibited a high FE for formate production, while at relatively negative potentials, where oxidized Sn was reduced to metallic Sn, the FE of formate generation significantly decreased. Among the various pathways of the CO2RR (shown in Table 1), the simultaneous production of hydrogen and carbon monoxide is considered to be extremely valuable, because the obtained product (syngas) can be utilized to produce more valuable chemicals [92,93]. Pd hydride (PdH) is recognized as a potential catalyst for the CO2RR, with the major product being a mixture of hydrogen and carbon monoxide. Lee et al.[94] synthesized a series of Pd alloys and studied the influence of the second metal on the CO2RR performance and formation of PdH. The in situ XAS results revealed that the presence of Ag and Cu did not interfere with the formation of PdH, while the presence of Pt on the Pd lattice hindered the formation of PdH due to strong binding between Pt and *H. SACs have also emerged as promising candidates for the electrochemical CO2RR [95–97]. Hu’s group [98] reported a single-atom Fe catalyst with ultrahigh activity for producing CO via the CO2RR. By comparing the in situ XAS results of the prepared Fe3+-N-C and Fe2+-N-C catalysts that were pyrolyzed from various precursors with distinct Fe-N coordination environments, they revealed that the pyrrolic type ligands in Fe3+-N-C are important for the stability of Fe3+, which is key for the high activity and selectivity for CO. Wang et al. [99] reported an active single-atom Zn catalyst for the CO2RR. In situ XAS measurements were also conducted to probe the real-time state of Zn during the CO2RR. Interestingly, their results suggested that the Zn center was redox-innocent throughout the potential range. Based on these results and those of cyclic voltammetry tests, they proposed that the porphyrin ligand may serve as a redox mediator. 7 Conclusion and perspective Recently, a growing number of in situ characterization techniques have been implemented to investigate various electrocatalytic processes, providing valuable insights for the rational design of efficient and robust catalysts [100–103]. Herein, we have summarized some notable applications of in situ Raman spectroscopy and XAS in various electrochemical reactions, including the ORR, OER, HOR/HER, and CO2RR. The application of in situ characterization techniques for detecting the electrocatalytic process of these reactions has contributed to elucidating important features, including: (1) the pathways occurring on the surface of various Pt single crystals; (2) the role of transition metals in Pt-based alloy systems; (3) possible active sites in M-N-C catalysts; (4) transformations and working mechanisms of some OER catalysts; (5) the function of OH− on HOR; (6) several active species that govern the activity and selectivity of CO2RR catalysts. These findings are of significant value for the future design of highly active electrocatalysts. Although after years of development, the sensitivity of Raman spectroscopy has been considerably improved, this advancement is strongly dependent on the use of enhanced substrates, which limits its further application for studying practical catalysts. Furthermore, as a surface-sensitive technique, SERS cannot directly provide information regarding characteristics such as the oxidation state, electronic structure, and coordination environment. Thus, more advanced strategies should be explored to enable the direct application of Raman spectroscopy in the characterization of practical catalysts, in conjunction with numerous other characterization techniques. As a bulk-sensitive technique, XAS can only reveal the average coordination number of target elements, which hinders the discovery of the real active moiety, especially for M-N-C catalysts. In addition, high-energy incident light may cause damage to the active sites or induce catalyst transformation. Therefore, it is vital to develop versatile techniques, such as surface-sensitive Δμ-XANES and soft XAS with shorter attenuation lengths, to compensate for the shortcomings of XAS. In addition to the limitations of these in situ techniques, multiple issues continue to prevent attaining a comprehensive understanding of these electrocatalysis processes. For example, in situ research should be transformed into operando research and conducted under real working conditions. In particular, the role of electrolytes should be taken into consideration. Another challenge is the lack of time-resolved techniques to reveal dynamic changes in the active species under varying potentials. Obtaining a Raman spectrum may take tens of seconds, while several minutes are required to obtain one XAS spectrum. coredata.dc:description: ABSTRACT Electrochemical energy conversion technologies involving processes such as water splitting and O2/CO2 reduction, provide promising solutions for addressing global energy scarcity and minimizing adverse environmental impact. However, due to a lack of an in-depth understanding of the reaction mechanisms and the nature of the active sites, further advancement of these techniques has been limited by the development of efficient and robust catalysts. Therefore, in situ characterization of these electrocatalytic processes under working conditions is essential. In this review, recent applications of in situ Raman spectroscopy and X-ray absorption spectroscopy for various nano- and single-atom catalysts in energy-related reactions are summarized. Notable cases are highlighted, including the capture of oxygen-containing intermediate species formed during the reduction of oxygen and oxidation of hydrogen, and the detection of catalyst structural transformations occurring with the change in potential during the evolution of oxygen and reduction of CO2. Finally, the challenges and outlook for advancing in situ spectroscopic technologies to gain a deeper fundamental understanding of these energy-related electrocatalytic processes are discussed.
